history.content:
I can't speak for 128 but EECS C106A/206A course staff will be working this summer to convert all labs to be done online using various simulation software and a VM so that students can still get the full experience of 106A (I was a 106A TA last semester and plan to be one next semester).

Currently in 128, the GSI created a Simulink block to simulate the labs' hardware so the labs were still completely doable with minimal changes. One lab was forced to be dropped though but maybe next year's TAs will find a way to make it doable online (or find a good replacement for it).

children.subject:
You do learn to deal with and work with hardware and the various issues that can arise with it however we don't teach you to actually build or design any of your own hardware in lab if that's what you're asking about or are interested in. Students use Baxters, Sawyers, and Turtlebots to complete labs and can use any sort of robot available to them for their final project.

If the school decides on having a hybrid semester, we will try to have in person labs while keeping social distancing practices in place so you would still be able to use the robots. If it's all online instruction, then unfortunately we will most likely be unable to use the robots but there are numerous simulation softwares available that can give you a pretty good sense of what it's like to work with real robots. 

I can't really tell you whether you should stay and take it or withdraw though. That's entirely up to you but this is what we are planning at the moment. It mostly depends on what the school decides and what creates the safest learning environment for our students. Hope this helps :)

Do you know if this will affect enrollment in the course? I heard people already would be up till 3-4 am working on labs becuase of constricted time slots last year, and this seems like it would make it worse. I am waitlisted for the course and sort of need it to graduate, and dont really know my prospects for the course.

We are currently unsure how it will affect enrollment. I'm assuming these people were actually talking about the final project, not the labs though. Labs can be mostly completed during lab section and there aren't sign ups to use the robots to finish up labs. For the final project, however, since most people elect to use our robots to do their project on, we provide a sign up sheet for people to reserve specific robots with rules in place to prevent one team from monopolizing any one robot. They tend to completely fill up in the last week or two of the semester (causing groups who still have work to do need to reserve a robot at odd hours like 3-4 am) but tend to be much more available during the first few weeks of the final project portion of the class.

I've heard that half of 106a ends up being learning ROS + kinematics + coordinate frames/etc which would work virtually, but the other valuable half is having a pretty major hardware-based project. I've been itching to have actual hands-on experience for like half of my undergrad, so if that gets axed, should I actually just withdraw?

history.content:
Title.

It's making me wonder if I should consider withdrawing for a semester or two instead of getting a lesser experience.
history.subject: How will classes like EE C106A and C128 work in the hybrid or fully online course format?
